titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Paul Ceruzzi papers, 1990s-2000s

did.head: Descriptive Summary

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: George Mason University. Libraries. Special Collections Research Center.

did.abstract: The Paul Ceruzzi Papers contain Paul Ceruzzi's research done while writing his book "Internet Alley: High Technology in Tysons Corner, 1945-2005." It also contains some materials concerning the development of the area after the publishing of the book.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: There are no restrictions on personal use. Permission to publish material from the Paul Ceruzzi Papers must be obtained from the Special Collections Research Center, George Mason University Libraries.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Paul Ceruzzi Papers, C0306, Special Collections Research Center, George Mason University Libraries.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processing completed by Zac Greenfield in August 2017. EAD markup completed by Zac Greenfield in August 2017.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Paul Ceruzzi is Curator of aerospace and electronics at the National Air and Space Museum in Washington D.C. Dr. Ceruzzi attended Yale University and the University of Kansas, acquiring his PhD in American Studies in 1981. He has authored or co-authored several books in addition to "Internet Alley," such as "Computing, A Concise History" and "Beyond the Limits: Flight Enters the Computer Age," among many others.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Donated by Paul Ceruzzi in June 2017.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This collection is an extensive gathering of local Fairfax County history as it relates to the development of computational technology in the Northern Virginia region. There is a lot of military history from the Cold War, weapons development programs, as well as the development of the public face of the Internet. Dr. Ceruzzi's research ranged from the development of Tysons Corner as a small hamlet to the bustling office and shopping center it eventually became. His work collected here shows the many aspects of Northern Virginia that were involved not only in the growth of the Internet and the local region as a suburb of D.C. but also the constant presence of military and government officials, some less subtle than others. The collection is made up of research papers, declassified military intelligence documents, research done by the various contractor corporations that were drawn to the region, and interviews with prominent individuals, such as Til Hazel and George Johnson, former president of George Mason University. Also included were several empty folders, which have been removed from the collection. The titles of these folders were "NSFnet, circa 1995," "Radio Tower" and "Tower Pix."
The collection is made up of papers, photographs, maps, and newspapers.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged mostly alphabetically, kept in original order.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: The Special Collections Research Center also holds the papers of other Northern Virginia development projects, including several on Reston, such as the and the , as well as several others.
